questions.text: You require to provide aggressive volume resuscitation for a patient of trauma with hypovolemic shock. Which catheter will allow fastest resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Flow in the peripheral catheters is at least 4 times greater than flow in the lumen of equivalent diameter in the central venous catheter.

This demonstrates why short, large-bore peripheral catheters are preferred to central venous catheters for aggressive volume resuscitation.

Reference: Marino's The ICU Book, 4th edition, pg 204

questions.text: Match the following labels with the levels of brachial plexus blocks:
questions.solution:
• An interscalene brachial plexus block is indicated for procedures involving the shoulder and upper arm. Roots C5-7 are most densely blocked with this approach.
  • A supraclavicular brachial plexus block can provide dense anesthesia for procedures at or distal to the elbow at the level of the divisions.
  • An infraclavicular brachial plexus block at the level of the cords
  • Provides excellent anesthesia for procedures at or distal to the elbow
  • An axillary brachial plexus block is administered at the lateral border of the pectoralis minor muscle where the cords of the brachial plexus form large terminal 6 branches.

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's clinical anesthesiology, 6th edition, pg 1005-14.

questions.text: A patent has to undergo neurosurgery for intracranial space occupying lesion, inhalational agent of choice (for TICT) is:
questions.solution:
• Isoflurane has least & methoxyflurane has highest fluoride content
  • Methoxyflurane causes
    • Vasopressin resistant high output (pyloric) renal failure
    • Oxalate stones
  • Fluoride content & so nephrotoxicity in decreasing order is
    • Methoxyflurane > Enflurane & Sevoflurane (only on prolonged use significant fluoride content & nephrotoxicity) > Halothane
    • Isoflurane & Desflurane (can be used in renal failure; only desflurane does not decrease RBF, GFR & urine output).

Reference: Drugs in Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, Edward Scarth, Susan Smith, 5th edition; Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anaesthetic practice, 3rd edition.

questions.text: After emergence from anesthesia, 30 years old female shows features of delirium in the postoperative period. Which anesthetic agent must have been used to cause these complications?
questions.solution:
• Emergence from ketamine anesthesia in the postoperative period may be associated with visual, auditory, proprioceptive, and confusion like illusions, which may progress to Delirium
  • Cortical blindness may be present transiently.
  • Dreams and hallucinations can occur up to 24 hours after administration of ketamine
  • The dreams frequently have a morbid content and are often experienced in vivid color
  • Dreams and hallucinations usually disappear within a few hours
  • Propofol is known to have a clear-headed recovery on emergence

Reference: Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anesthetic practice, 5th edition, Pg. 192

questions.text: A 48 years old female is being induced for general anaesthesia with propofol. Which of the following effects can be minimized by giving lignocaine earlier to injecting Propofol?
questions.solution:
Propofol produces a 15-25% decrease in the blood pressure (option a) and systemic vascular resistance, without a compensatory increase in the heart rate; the cardiac output decreases by 20%

Option c: Pain on injection occurs in up to 28% of subjects. The incidence may be reduced by the addition of lidocaine (1 ml of 1%), cooling the drug, and the use of large veins.

Option d: Bolus administration of propofol produces apnea of variable duration (30 to ≥60 seconds) and suppression of laryngeal reflexes. Infusion of the drug produces a decrease in the tidal volume, tachypnea, and a depressed ventilatory response to hypercarbia and hypoxia.

Reference: Drugs in Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, Edward Scarth, Susan Smith, 5th edition, pg 326.

choices.text: Precurarization reduces fasciculations and myalgia associated with Sch
Produces both phase I and phase II block

questions.text: The following statements are true regarding succinylcholine (Sch) except?
questions.solution:
• Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant
  • It produces both phase I and phase II (at higher dose)
  • Succinylcholine can produce a rise in intracranial pressure because of increased cerebral blood flow due to muscle fasciculations
  • Precurarization is the administration of a small dose (10% of ED95) of a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent a few minutes before Sch to minimize the complications of Sch use like
    • Fasciculations
    • Post-operative myalgia
    • Rise in intragastric pressure
    • Rise in ICP

Reference: Morgan and mikhail's clinical anaesthesiology, 6th edition.

questions.text: Sugammadex is used for the reversal of
questions.solution:
• Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin
  • It is the first selective relaxant binding agent
  • It exerts its reversal effect by forming tight complexes in a 1:1 ratio with Steroidal nondepolarizing agents(rocuronium > vecuronium >> pancuronium)
  • Sugammadex is essentially eliminated unchanged via the kidneys

Reference: Morgan and mikhail's clinical anaesthesiology, 6th edition.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient is admitted for TIPSS (trans jugular intrahepatic Porto systemic shunt) procedure. He is an alcoholic, known case of chronic Liver disease and hepatorenal syndrome. The plan is to give general anesthesia. The muscle relaxant of choice will be
questions.solution:
• Atracurium has Two modes of metabolism:
  • Ester hydrolysis (60% of dose) in plasma by non-specific esterases to laudanosine, a quaternary acid and alcohol.
  • Hofmann degradation, i.e., spontaneous breakdown to laudanosine and monoacrylate. This occurs at body temp and pH. Acidosis and cold slow the rate of degradation.

Others metabolism: Vecuronium-liver, Rocuronium-duration of action prolonged in liver/renal disease.

Reference: FRCA A TO Z, page no 56

questions.text: The most potent local anesthetic among the following is?
questions.solution:
• Based on potency, local anesthetics are classified as:
    1. Low Potency
      • Procaine
    2. Intermediate Potency
      • Mepivacaine
      • Prilocaine
      • Chloroprocaine
      • Lidocaine
    3. High Potency
      • Tetracaine
      • Bupivacaine
      • Etidocaine
  • The potency of local anesthetics correlates with their hydrophobicity. Hydrophobic molecules → more potent and longer acting
  • Receptor site of action of local anesthetics on Na channel is hydrophobic, hence they have a high affinity for hydrophobic compounds
  • Hydrophobicity of a local anesthetic is expressed as octanol/buffer partitioning which reflects the lipophilic-hydrophilic interaction
  • Hydrophobicity can be increased by the addition of alkyl groups to the molecule

Reference: Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anaesthetic practice, 5th edition.

choices.text: A gamma > A delta > A alpha > B > C
A alpha > B > C > A gamma > A delta
B > C >A gamma > A delta > A alpha
C >A gamma > A delta > A alpha > B

questions.text: The correct order of susceptibility of nerve fibers to local anesthetic agents
questions.solution:
• Sensitivity of nerve fibers to inhibition by local anesthetics is influenced by axonal diameter, myelination, and other factors.
  • In comparing nerve fibers of the same type (myelinated versus unmyelinated), smaller diameter associates with increased sensitivity to local anesthetics.
  • Thus, larger, faster-conducting Aα fibers are less sensitive to local anesthetics than smaller, slower-conducting Aδ fibers.
  • Larger unmyelinated fibers are less sensitive than smaller unmyelinated fibers.
  • On the other hand, small unmyelinated C fibers are relatively resistant to inhibition by local anesthetics as compared with larger myelinated fibers.
  • In a human peripheral nerve, the onset of local anesthetic inhibition generally follows this sequence: autonomic before sensory before motor.

Reference: Morgan anesthesia, edition 6, page no 264

questions.text: A 28 years old female, a case of severe preeclampsia, has been administered magnesium sulphate in the labor room, following which decision has been taken to opt for an emergency LSCS due to fetal bradycardia. All drug doses have to be reduced after administering magnesium sulphate except
questions.solution:
• Magnesium enhances the effects of other CNs depressants and NMB agents; 30-50% of the normal dose of non-depolarizing relaxants should be used to maintain neuromuscular blockade in the presence of magnesium sulfate.
  • Acute administration of magnesium sulfate prior to the use of suxamethonium appears to prevent potassium release and may reduce the incidence and severity of muscle pains.
  • It does not affect local anesthetic doses.

Reference: Drugs in Anesthesia and Intensive Care, Edward Scarth, Susan Smith, 5th edition, pg 235

questions.text: For an awake craniotomy in a patient with an intracerebral tumour, wake up test is planned during the surgery. Which opioid would be the best for analgesia and sedation in such patients?
questions.solution:
• During awake craniotomy, short acting anesthetics should be used since emergence and onset of anesthesia and sedation promptly is required for such cases
  • Remifentanyl has unique pharmacokinetics, which allow rapid onset of drug effect, precise titration to the desired effect, the ability to maintain enough effect-site concentration to suppress the stress response, and rapid recovery from the drug's effects
  • Thus, it is ideal for awake craniotomies than other opioid analgesics.

Reference: Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anaesthetic practice, 5th edition, pg. 238.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man known to have COPD is admitted with severe respiratory distress. What is the flow rate required to deliver 28% oxygen through a venturi mask?
questions.solution:
The FiO2 delivered by venturi mask depends on the oxygen flow rate and the amount of air entrained. The amount of air entrained depends on the venturi mask adaptors. There are slits in the venturi mask adaptors, which become smaller or larger depending on whether a high or lower FIO2 is required. These slits are designed to entrain air from the environment. Therefore, the set oxygen flow and the entrained air together meet the inspiratory flow requirement of the patient

Reference: Al-Shaikh B, Stacey S, Eds. Fixed performance devices. In: Essentials of anaesthetic equipment, 3rd ed. London, UK: Churchill Livingstone, Elsevier, 2007; Chapter 6: 89-91.

questions.text: Identify the following equipment which is often used for Covid 19 patients:
questions.solution:
• The given image is of an NRBM, which can deliver upto 100% O2 theoretically to a spontaneously breathing patient.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7451005/

questions.text: Endotracheal intubation was done for a patient. Which of the following will you do to confirm the placement of ET tube?
questions.solution:
• ETCO2 or normal capnogram is the surest way to confirm the position of the ET tube.
  • Signs of correct placement of ET tube - chest lift, mist formation, auscultate, ETCO2, CXR.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, pg 1398

questions.text: A patient is undergoing a surgery where anesthesia is maintained on Halothane. The patient developed muscle rigidity and hyperthermia. Which of the following agent would have also contributed to this condition?
questions.solution:
This is a case of malignant hyperthermia (MH), a life-threatening condition triggered by volatile anesthetics like Halothane and depolarizing muscle relaxants such as succinylcholine in genetically susceptible individuals. MH is characterized by muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, acidosis, and hyperkalemia.

Treatment: Administration of Dantrolene: This is the definitive treatment. Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant that inhibits calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, reversing the excessive muscle contraction.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, pg 1120

questions.text: An anaesthetist was doing shoulder block with 0.25% bupivacaine, the patient become unresponsive and pulse become unrecordable. The best management in this patient would be
questions.solution:
• Local anesthesia systemic toxicity can be treated with 20% intralipid emulsion along with CPR if the patient becomes unconscious.
  • Cardiotoxicity and CNS toxicity are seen in the toxicity of local anesthetics like bupivacaine and levobupivacaine.
  • Intralipid decreases cardiac bupivacaine concentration by 11% within 3 minutes of administration and cerebral bupivacaine content by 18% within 15 minutes of administration.

Reference: Miller's anesthesia, 9th edition, pg 885

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of potency of anesthetic agents?
questions.solution:
• Potency is inversely proportional to MAC i.e. agents with high MAC will have low MAC.
  • N2O has highest MAC, hence it is least potent. Methoxyflurane has lowest MAC, hence it is the most potent.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, pg 565

choices.text: Flow of CO2during exhalation which is low
Flow of CO2 during exhalation which is normal
Flow of CO2 during exhalation which is high
Flow of CO2 during inhalation which is normal

questions.text: You are an intern posted in an OT, you are asked to identify the marked arrow
questions.solution:
• The given image shows capnography.
  • It is showing ETCO2 which is flow of CO2 during exhalation which is normal.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, pg: 1311

questions.text: What is the gauge for given image of canula?
questions.solution:
1. Orange (14G):
    • Gauge: 14
    • Flow rate: 240 mL/min
    • Use: Rapid fluid resuscitation in trauma, shock, or emergencies where large volumes of fluid are required quickly.
  2. Grey (16G):
    • Gauge: 16
    • Flow rate: 180 mL/min
    • Use: Blood transfusions, large-volume fluid infusions in surgery, or emergency settings.
  3. Green (18G):
    • Gauge: 18
    • Flow rate: 90-105 mL/min
    • Use: Blood transfusions, large-volume infusions, commonly used in hospitalized patients for routine IV access.
  4. Pink (20G):
    • Gauge: 20
    • Flow rate: 60-65 mL/min
    • Use: Routine IV infusions, medications, blood transfusions; commonly used for adults.
  5. Blue (22G):
    • Gauge: 22
    • Flow rate: 36 mL/min
    • Use: Suitable for pediatric, elderly patients, or those with smaller veins. Used for IV medications, fluids.
  6. Yellow (24G):
    • Gauge: 24
    • Flow rate: 20 mL/min
    • Use: Neonatal or pediatric patients, very fragile veins, or for slow infusions.
  7. Violet (26G):
    • Gauge: 26
    • Flow rate: ~10-13 mL/min
    • Use: Primarily used in neonates or very small veins in critically ill patients

Reference: https://www.medilogbiohealth.com/2022/02/cannula.html

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency with acute pancreatitis and was shifted to ICU and intubated. The patient was receiving pressure-controlled continuous mandatory ventilation (PC-CMV) with a set pressure of 20 cm H2O and a current PEEP setting of 5 cm H2O. PaO2 is 110mmHg with FiO2 of 50%. Auscultation reveals bi-basilar crackles and scattered crackles in the posterior basal segments. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The crackles in the basilar and posterior areas may indicate atelectasis and the opening and closing of alveoli in dependent areas. An increase in PEEP is indicated, and a recruitment manoeuvre might also be considered.

Reference: Pilbeam's Mechanical ventilation, 6th edition, Ch-17, Pg-321

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy reported to emergency with breathing difficulty. ECG and capnography images are shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option a: Myocarditis

The most common ECG abnormalities seen in myocarditis are:

  • Sinus tachycardia
  • Non-specific ST segment and T waves changes

Option b: Acute asthma

Ecg is normal.

Below image shows the normal capnogram

A capnogram with increased α angle is normally caused by airway obstruction, either mechanical (tracheal tube kinking or blockade by secretions or foreign body) or pathological (bronchial asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). Capnogram image looks like a Shark fin.

Option c: ECG may be helpful, especially if it shows low voltages or electrical alternans, which is the classic ECG finding in cardiac tamponade due to the swinging of the heart within the pericardium that is filled with fluid.

This is a rare ECG finding, and most commonly the ECG finding of cardiac tamponade is sinus tachycardia.

Option d: Pericarditis

  • Widespread concave ST elevation and PR depression throughout most of the limb leads (I, II, III, aVL, aVF) and precordial leads (V2-6)
  • Reciprocal ST depression and PR elevation in lead aVR (± V1)
  • Sinus tachycardia is also common in acute pericarditis due to pain and/or pericardial effusion

Reference: Understanding Anesthetic Equipment & Procedures- A Practical Approach by Dwarkadas K Baheti( Ch-28, pg-301)

choices.text: Perform a TMT and if normal, proceed with surgery
Repeat the echocardiogram and if normal, proceed with surgery

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is scheduled for a thyroidectomy. During the pre-operative assessment, she reports experiencing chest pain two weeks ago and consulted a cardiologist, who prescribed antianginal medications. Her ECG shows no new changes, and an echocardiogram performed at the time revealed an ejection fraction of 63%. What is the most appropriate course of action?
questions.solution:
According to the latest ACC/AHA guidelines, elective surgeries should be deferred for at least 60 days following a recent myocardial infarction (MI), even if no new ECG changes are present and the patient is asymptomatic.

  • Option A: A treadmill test (TMT) can be risky in patients with a recent history of chest pain. Instead, a stress echocardiogram is preferred, but since the surgery is elective, it's better to delay the procedure.
  • Option B: A repeat echocardiogram is unnecessary unless the patient develops new symptoms, as the prior echo showed a normal ejection fraction (63%).
  • Option C: There is no need to permanently cancel the surgery; after 2 months, the patient's risk of re-infarction is reduced.

Thus, the best decision is to defer the surgery for 2 months to reduce the risk of perioperative cardiac events.

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status Classification

  • ASA-PS 1:A normal, healthy patient
    → Healthy, non-smoker, minimal or no alcohol use.
  • ASA-PS 2:A patient with mild systemic disease
    → Current smoker, well-controlled diabetes mellitus (DM) and hypertension (HTN).
  • ASA-PS 3:A patient with severe systemic disease
    → Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history of myocardial infarction (MI), cerebrovascular accident (CVA), transient ischemic attack (TIA), or coronary artery disease (CAD) with stents more than 3 months ago.
  • ASA-PS 4:A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life
    → Recent (<3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD with stents.
  • ASA-PS 5:A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation
    → Examples include ruptured abdominal or thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, or intracranial bleed with mass effect.
  • ASA-PS 6:A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page 932

questions.text: In infants, the spinal cord extends up to which vertebral level?
questions.solution:
In infants, the spinal cord extends to approximately the lower border of the L3 vertebra. This is because, during intrauterine life, the spinal cord occupies the entire vertebral canal. However, as the vertebral column grows more rapidly than the spinal cord after birth, the cord's termination level shifts.

  • In Infancy: The spinal cord ends at the lower border of L3.
  • In Adulthood: The spinal cord typically terminates at the lower border of L1. This anatomical change is achieved by about 2 years of age.

Clinical Significance:

  • In infants: Spinal anesthesia should be administered below the L3-L4 intervertebral space to avoid injury to the spinal cord. Avoiding L3-4 and any space above is critical due to the risk of cephalad movement of the needle potentially injuring the spinal cord.
  • In adults: Spinal anesthesia should not be performed above the L1-L2 space because the spinal cord can extend up to L1 in some individuals.
  • The dura mater extends to S2, while the pia mater, in the form of the filum terminale, extends to the coccyx.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page 1414

choices.text: First step is to start CPR
After assessing the airway, breathing, and circulation, the next step is to call for emergency medical services
After assessing the airway, breathing, and circulation, the next step is 5 cycles of CPR
After assessing the airway, breathing, and circulation, the next step is defibrillation

questions.text: A 5-year-old patient presents in cardiorespiratory arrest at the emergency department. What is the correct next step in basic life support (BLS) after assessing the airway, breathing, and circulation?
questions.solution:
In the case of an unwitnessed cardiac arrest in a child:

  1. Initial Assessment: Before starting CPR, assess the patient's responsiveness, airway, breathing, and circulation.
  2. Basic Life Support Steps:
    • In unwitnessed cardiac arrest, it is recommended to start with 5 cycles of CPR before calling for emergency medical services. This is because the cause of the cardiac arrest in children is often due to respiratory issues or other non-cardiac reasons, making immediate CPR crucial.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A: CPR should only be started after assessing consciousness, breathing, and circulation.
  • Option B: In adults with unwitnessed cardiac arrest, emergency medical services should be called immediately after assessment for potential defibrillation if needed. In children, however, starting CPR first is prioritized.
  • Option D: Defibrillation is performed only if there is a shockable rhythm (e.g., ventricular fibrillation), which would be confirmed by a monitor.

In BLS for children, 5 cycles of CPR are performed before calling for emergency medical services, ensuring that resuscitation efforts are in place before external help arrives.

Reference: Miller's Review of Orthopaedics, 9th Edition, Pages 2716-2717
